raw_text:
Preview: Ireland v England (Sun)
 
 Lansdowne Road, Dublin
 
 Sunday, 27 February
 
 1500 GMT
 
 BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website
 
 Ireland are going for their first Grand Slam since 1948 after two opening wins, and England represent their sternest test of the Championship so far. England were sloppy and leaderless in the defeats against Wales and France and another loss would be unthinkable. The pressure is on coach Andy Robinson and his side have to deliver.
 
 Despite England's dramatic dip in form since the World Cup final - they have lost eight of their last 13 matches - Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan says his side should not underestimate the visitors. "Had they kicked their points they would have beaten France and that would have created a different landscape for Sunday," he said. "This is England we are talking about. They have a depth of talent and a very good record against Ireland. "They will target a victory in Dublin as the turning point in their Six Nations." The differences between the sides is also highlighted in the team selections for the Dublin encounter.
 
 Ireland, despite having Gordon D'Arcy still out injured, have been boosted by the return of star skipper Brian O'Driscoll who missed the Scotland game with a hamstring injury. "The knowledge that the England game was coming up really helped during rehabilitation," he said. "The will to play in this game was enormous. It doesn't get much bigger than England at home." As well as entering the tournament without players like Jonny Wilkinson, Mike Tindall and Richard Hill, England have now lost two tighthead props in Julian White and Phil Vickery while blind-side flanker Lewis Moody is a major concern. Robinson, who received a lot of flak for the inclusion and then dropping of centre Mathew Tait, has kept faith with kicking fly-half Charlie Hodgson despite his horror show at Twickenham. If England slump in Dublin, it will be their worst run of results in the Championship since 1987.
 
 But Robinson was bullish during the week about the game, saying that his side "are going there to get in their faces", and has identified the line-out and tackle area as the key to England's chances. And despite the recent results, skipper Jason Robinson believes there is nothing wrong with the mood in the camp. "There is no lack of confidence in the team," said the Sale full-back. "We have had a good week's training and we are all looking forward to the challenge. "I still believe in this team. I know if we get our game right we will win the games."
 
 G Murphy; G Dempsey, B O'Driscoll, S Horgan, D Hickie; R O'Gara, P Stringer; R Corrigan, S Byrne, J Hayes; M O'Kelly, P O'Connell; S Easterby, J O'Connor, A Foley.
 
 F Sheahan, M Horan, D O'Callaghan, E Miller, G Easterby, D Humphreys, K Maggs.
 
 J Robinson (capt); M Cueto, J Noon, O Barkley, J Lewsey; C Hodgson, H Ellis; G Rowntree, S Thompson, M Stevens; D Grewcock, B Kay; J Worsley, L Moody, M Corry.
 
 A Titterrell, D Bell, S Borthwick, A Hazell, M Dawson, A Goode, O Smith.
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland are looking to win their first Grand Slam since 1948 and face England's sternest test of the Championship in Dublin. Despite England's recent form slump, Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan believes they should not underestimate the visitors.

England have a depth of talent and a good record against Ireland but will target victory in Dublin as the turning point in their Six Nations. Key players include skipper Jason Robinson, who remains confident despite England's poor run.

Ireland face challenges with injured skipper Brian O'Driscoll and concern over blind-side flanker Lewis Moody. However, captain Brian O'Driscoll remains optimistic about the team's mood, saying there is "no lack of confidence in the team".
llama3.2:3b: Ireland is seeking their first Grand Slam since 1948 against England in Dublin on February 27, with the pressure on coach Andy Robinson to deliver a victory that would be a turning point for his team. Despite a poor run of results since the World Cup final, Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan believes his side should not underestimate England's depth of talent and good record against them. England has been boosted by the return of star skipper Brian O'Driscoll, who will play in the Dublin game despite being injured just a week ago, but also faces injury concerns for several players, including Lewis Moody and Julian White.
gemma2:2b: Ireland is aiming for their first Grand Slam since 1948 and will face England in a crucial Six Nations match at Lansdowne Road. England's recent form has been poor, but they are facing a strong Irish side that will be motivated by the home crowd. Ireland has made several key returns while England is dealing with injuries and lineup changes.  England must overcome this to avoid their worst run of results in the Championship since 1987. Both sides have high-pressure situations.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
### Summary of the Text

Ireland v England (Sun) at Lansdowne Road, Dublin, 15:00 GMT.

• Ireland are undefeated since their World Cup final loss and have beaten Wales, France and others.
• England's opponents will face a tough schedule, needing to win three matches out of six to qualify for the Six Nations tournament.
• Coach Andy Robinson calls his side "England we are talking about" and has faith in their attacking capabilities.
• The Irish team includes star players Gordon D'Arcy and Brian O'Driscoll but has added injuries, replacements, and concerns about other players.
• Ireland's hopes of winning at Lansdowne Road depend heavily on England’s performance and the weather conditions.
qwen2.5:1.5b:
### Summary:
Ireland faces England in Dublin for their first Grand Slam since 1948. Despite recent poor form and injuries, Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan insists they can't underestimate the reigning champions, who are ranked high against them. Both teams' selections highlight significant differences: England has lost key players like Jonny Wilkinson, while Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll returns from injury to boost confidence after a tough World Cup season. Robinson calls on England to "get in their faces" as he prepares for the highly anticipated game at Lansdowne Road.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland face England at Lansdowne Road in a crucial Six Nations match after Ireland's two opening wins and England's recent poor form including losses to Wales and France. Pressure is on both teams as Ireland aim for their first Grand Slam since 1948, while Eddie O'Sullivan praises Brian O'Driscoll's return but acknowledges England's depth of talent and good record against them. Despite losing key players like Jonny Wilkinson and Phil Vickery, England coach Andy Robinson remains confident in his side, focusing on line-out and tackle areas. Ireland captain Jason Robinson maintains team confidence despite recent poor results, while England hopes to avoid their worst run of Championship results since 1987.

Ireland v England (Sun)
  
Lansdowne Road, Dublin

Sunday, 27 February

15:00 GMT

BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website

Ireland are going for their first Grand Slam since 19th after two opening wins. They represent their sternest test of the Championship so far. England were sloppy and leaderless in the defeats against Wales and France and another loss would be unthinkable. The pressure is on coach Andy Robinson and his side have to deliver.

Despite England's dramatic dip in form since the World Cup final, they have lost eight of their last 13 matches. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan says his side should not underestimate the visitors. "Had they kicked their points they would have beaten France and that would have created a different landscape for Sunday," he said. The differences between the sides is also highlighted in the team selections for the Dublin encounter.

Ireland, despite having Gordon D'Arcy still out injured, have been boosted by the return of skipper Brian O’Driscoll who missed the Scotland game with a hamstring injury. The knowledge that the England game was coming up really helped during rehabilitation. "The will to play in this game was enormous. It doesn't get much bigger than England at home." As well as entering the tournament without players like Jonny Wilkinson, Mike Tindall and Richard Hill, England have now lost two tighthead props in Julian White and Phil Vickery while blind-side flanker Lewis Moody is a major concern. 

Robinson, who received a lot of flak for the inclusion and then dropping of centre Mathew Tait, has kept faith with kicking fly-half Charlie Hodgson despite his horror show at Twickenham. If England slump in Dublin, it will be their worst run of results in the Championship since 1987.

But Robinson was bullish during the week about the game, saying that his side "are going there to get in their faces". The team has identified the line-out and tackle area as the key to England's chances. Despite the recent results, skipper Jason Robinson believes there is nothing wrong with the mood in the camp. "There is no lack of confidence in the team," said the Sale full-back. "We have had a good week’s training and we are all looking forward to the challenge. We believe in this team. I know if we get our game right we will win the games."

<think>

First, I'll read through the preview carefully. It mentions that Ireland has their first Grand Slam since 1948, so that's a big deal for them. England was too hard on Tuesday with Wales and France, and they probably won't be easy again. The pressure is on Andy Robinson as coach.

The preview also talks about Eddie O'Sullivan saying his side shouldn't underestimate the visitors. He mentions England having depth and fighting spirit against Ireland. They're aiming for a victory in Dublin, which would be their best result since 1987.

There are some specific details from the game: England lost eight out of thirteen matches after the World Cup final, including Julian White and Phil Vickery losing to Blundeville. But Robinson is optimistic about the match, thinking England might do well because they have a good team. He mentions Mathew Tait's recent poor form but is confident if he kicks Charlie Hodgson.

The team selections are listed with various players missing or struggling, like Jonny Wilkinson and Mike Tindall. Robinson is a full-back, and there's mention of other key positions too.

The user wants only the summary in plain text without explanations, so I need to make sure not to include any reasoning or formatting.

I should condense all this into concise points: Ireland's first Grand Slam since 1948, England's tough recent results, Robinson's focus, England's depth and fighting spirit, team compositions including missing players, and the turning point at Dublin as their best chance.

I'll make sure to include key names like Eddie O'Sullivan, Andy Robinson, Gordie D'Arcy, Brian O'Driscoll, etc. Also, note that Robinson has faith in his team despite recent struggles.

Let me structure it into short paragraphs or bullet points without any fluff. Make sure each main point is clear and not too detailed.
</think>

The preview discusses a thrilling 1947 Six Nations Championship match between Ireland and England. Ireland claimed their first Grand Slam since 1948, while England faced a tough test with two consecutive defeats in the World Cup final. Robinson emphasized that his team should focus on turning the tide at home against England, which was expected to be their best result since 1987. The match features key players like Eddie O'Sullivan, with Robinson expecting England's depth and fighting spirit against Ireland. Team compositions reveal missing players and potential issues, but Robinson remains optimistic about England's performance.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Irish rugby team will be looking to win their first Grand Slam since the 1948 season after a 2-0 defeat by England in the Six Nations Championship match on Sunday (February 27). However, coach Eddie O'Sullivan is confident his side can deliver and believes they have the necessary depth of talent to overcome England. The game will be broadcast live on BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website. Despite recent losses, skipper Jason Robinson has identified the line-out and tackle area as the key to England's chaos in the Championship. Coach Andy Robinson believes Ireland have a depth of talent but emphasises that the pressure is on England to deliver after their defeat against Wales and loss to France. The players were boosted by the return of star skipper Brian O'Druscoll, who had been injured during rehab, while wing Mike Tipten and blind-side flanker Lewis Mood are worried about their futures in the side due to injuries. England's woes continue with the loss of two key props but Robinson believes his team can still win despite their poor record against Ireland. The game will be broadcast live on BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The Six Nations Championship kicks off on Sunday with England facing Ireland at the Lansdowne Road in Dublin. This marks the first time since 1948 that they have gone undefeated in this Championship. It's a significant moment for both sides and a chance to shine against an opponent who may not be at their best.

As England continue to search for their footing, Ireland has undergone significant changes since the World Cup final, losing several players due to injuries. Coach Andy Robinson is expected to make some key selections based on the team's performance in the upcoming match against France and Italy. This match will be an important moment for both teams as they prepare for their respective matches.

As England's kicking game continues to struggle, they are relying heavily on their tighthead prop Jonny Wilkinson to score tries. However, this is not a guarantee that they will win the game against Ireland. If England can find their kicking game and avoid making costly errors, they could potentially overturn a large deficit and surprise some people.

Despite England's poor recent form in Six Nations Championship, there is no reason to expect them to be out of reach for Ireland. However, with pressure on coach Eddie O'Sullivan, it will be important for him and his team to deliver a strong performance and make the necessary adjustments to counteract any possible weaknesses in their opponents.
phi:2.7b: Ireland and England are set to face each other in the Six Nations Championship. Ireland won their last Grand Slam over 24 years ago and has two opening wins against Wales and France. However, England's coach Andy Robinson believes his side can still win and they will target a victory as it would be a turning point for them. The teams have different approaches with Ireland having players like Gordon D'Arcy who is back from injury while England has lost two tight-head props and blindside flanker Lewis Moody. Despite their recent results, skipper Jason Robinson remains confident in his team. They believe the line-out and tackle area are key to England's chances.
orca-mini:3b: The upcoming Six Nations match between Ireland and England is scheduled to take place on February 27th at Lansdowne Road in Dublin. Both teams have a lot riding on this game as they look to improve their respective records in the tournament. Ireland are gunning for their first Grand Slam since 1948, while England are facing their sternest test of the Championship so far. The match will be broadcasted on BBC1, Radio 4 LW and this website. Despite losing two tighthead props and having a struggling kicking fly-half, England coach Andy Robinson has kept faith with Charlie Hodgson. However, there is concern over Lewis Moody's health. Ireland have welcomed back star skipper Brian O'Driscoll and Gordon D'Arcy but still lack the depth of talent compared to England. Despite the recent results, skipper Jason Robinson believes there is nothing wrong with the mood in the camp. The match will be a battle of line-outs and tackle areas as both teams look to get in each other's faces.
